Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 01:48PM LouLou40 wrote: My Chemo was ACx4, Taxol x 12 weekly. The Herceptin started with the Taxol every 3 weeks and continued for the year. I tolerated the Chemo and Herceptin well only minimal SE's from Chemo, just fatigue and a bit of nausea, my blood counts were great the whole time and I didn't require and Neulasta. I didn't even have a cold through Chemo and I have little kids. I have no residual effects from the Chemo 1 yr on except menopause. I didn't notice any SE's with the Herceptin and went back to work as a nurse as soon as I finished Rads. Hormone therapy has been the tricky bit for me, Chemo sent me into Menopause so I went onto Arimidex with 3 months blood tests to check I was still in menopause, however my bone density has dropped at an alarming rate due to no estrogen also I'm white and small framed which are also risk factors for osteoporosis. My Onc has stopped Arimidex or any other AI for good and started Zometa for the osteoporosis. I am not on any hormone therapy now as Tamox would have only given me a 2% reduction in risk of recurrence as my hormone receptors are low, so while I'm in menopause I have low estrogen so I'm comfortable without anything. Will review if my period returns.
Posts.Title: ER+,PR+, HER@+++Prememo Gals motherofpatient bcfighter

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 01:41PM LouLou40 wrote: My finger tips were numb to the bottom of my finger nail level by half way through my 12 weeks of Taxol, if it reached my 1st joint my Onc said he would stop it and change to something else - it never reached that level. My feet were very painful especially of a night with a burning, tingggling pain, but no numbness in my toes, my big toe nails lifted and become infected in the last couple of weeks.  After I finished 12 weeks of Taxol my finger got better very quickly within weeks they were back to normal, my feet took about 9 months for the pain to go, I took over the counter analgesia for moths at bedtime. I finished Chemo Aug 09 and I'm completly back to how I felt pre Chemo now. I would be guided by my Onc when it's time to stop Taxol as neuropathy can be permenant. LL
Posts.Title: DD Taxol and Neuropathy, quit early? her2intn LouLou40

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2010 12:21AM LouLou40 wrote: I had blurry vision for the first few days after my first AC, has real trouble reading, no way I could drive the car safely. I discovered with the second  around that it was related to the Dexamethosone not the AC chemo as my Onc forgot to order the Dex and my vision was perfect. I refused the Dex for my last 2 AC's and had no further issues with blurry vision, did have red, watery eyes in the third week post AC each time, not sure why, tried drops but nothing worked. My eye's went back to normal once I finished Chemo.
Posts.Title: Anyone have Eye Problems with AC Lovelyface anonymice

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 05:14AM LouLou40 wrote: My hair grew back during weekly taxol and 3 weekly herceptin, it was thick and fluffy all over by the time I finished taxol. I know there is a thread suggesting that herceptin slows hair growth but I didn't experience slow growth. Initially it was clear, brownish fluff, before my natural brown color returned. It was curly for about a yr and then went back to being straight I stopped wearing a scarf during rads, and my hair was long enough to have it colored before I headed back to work 9 weeks post chemo finishing, it was a really weird tabby cat color so had a brown put through it to even out the color. Im now 2 and half yrs out from chemo and my hair is shoulder length and a have a nice ponytail again
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 06:01AM LouLou40 wrote: I was 39 when I started Chemo, period stopped after third AC and haven't had one since. I'm coming up to the 2 yr mark, my blood test indicate it will be permanent Menopause for me, my Onc initially thought there was a good chance it would come back, but he thinks it's permanent - yep it sucks to be in premature menopause, I have osteoporosis and I'm only 41.
Posts.Title: Return of menses LtotheK slanderson

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 02:51PM LouLou40 wrote: I actually had 2 tumors IDC 1.5cm and 2 cm in my left breast with 2 positive lymph nodes and had a lumpectomy as the 2 tumors were close together and could be removed in one excision. They were grade 3, Her2+, ER+, PR+ and involved 2 lymph nodes, I did have an axillary node clearance in the same surgery. I was told that I am at no more of risk of recurrence with lumpectomy and Rads verses a mastectomy. I did discuss mastectomy with my BS, Medical Onc and Rad Onc and all thought a mastectomy was not necessary and would not reduce my risk of recurrence, it was the Chemo, Rads, Herceptin and Arimidix that would stop the recurrence not a mastectomy. I'm only 40 and feel comfortable with my decision and after all the treatment I have had I am very happy not to be facing reconstruction. I'm not a worrier and really think I have done everything possible to prevent a recurrence. I
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy IsThisForReal IsThisForReal

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 11:49PM - edited Jan 15, 2010 11:58PM by LouLou40 I was told I had 2 nodes positive 2 days post surgery the day I left hospital. At my first follow-up visit with my BS one week post surgery in his rooms I found out I was ER+,PR+,HER+, he gave me a copy of my Path report also. I saw my Medical Onc a couple of days later to plan Chemo. Started Chemo exactly 3 weeks post surgery, had my port inserted in the morning and started Chemo in the afternoon. If you are considering having a Mastectomy you would be wise to do it before Rads and consult a Plastic surgeon for advice on reconstruction options. Once you have had Rads the skin is much thinner and impants may not be an option. Some women do not require Rads with a Mastectomy some do, your BS can advise if you would need Rads with a Mastectomy. LL LL
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy IsThisForReal IsThisForReal

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 02:24AM LouLou40 wrote: I found the weekly taxol, 3 weekly herceptin much easier than AC. I had no nausea with taxol and didn't experience any SE's till about week 7 when I would get mild bone, muscles aches and pain, but easily fixed with mild analgesia. I get sore feet from pheripheral neuropathy, more of a issue once i finished the taxol, but didn't effect me doing a lot of walking to get my fitness back and it resolved after a few months. I did get very tired towards the end and worked shorter days finishing mid afternoon so I could have a snooze. I didn't take oral steroids during chemo, only had some IV in my premed and I didn't have ant issues with reactions. Hoping taxol treats you kindly as well,

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 04:51PM LouLou40 wrote: Hi Ken3, Sorry you had you join us, I'm 39 and have 3 kids 3, 5,7 and while I found it tough during Chemo at times as I only have my DH for help, life does go on and some how you find an inner strength that you didn't know you have and you get through it, because you have to. DH still went to work each day to pay the bills and I managed to get to get a rest when the kids were at school and day care. I drove myself to treatment and was lucky in that I stay really well, I was very fit and healthy before I started so I'm sure that helped. It's been a year for me since dx and life has pretty much returned to normal now, I took 9 months of work did 6 months of Chemo and 6 weeks of Rads. I found it very overwhelming in the beginning, but once I had my treatment plan I found it much easier just to focus on getting through each stage of treatment. Now BC dosen't consume my every thought and Chemo is a distant memory, the whole BC experience feels like a bad dream. LL

I will ask my Onc next week if it's the Taxol or Arimidex, seems very minor in the big picture but really annoying having to use the pencil again to fill them in.. LL
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2010 10:43PM LouLou40 wrote: I only took the dexamethasone tabs with my first AC which gave me blurred vision and sleep disturbance. I also took a lot of anti-emetics with my first AC (zofran, maxalon)  which made me very constipated and miserable. For subsequent AC infusions I didn't take the dex tablets and only had Emend x 3 tabs for nausea and I felt much better, even the nausea was better than the first time. The taxol didn't cause me any issues until towards the end when I developed leg pain day 4-5, Claritin did help along with over the counter analgesia.

I'm too scared to ask my Onc if he has seen many recurrences now we have Herceptin for Her2+ early BC...........just wondering if anybody knows how many women have a recurrence? I'm not worried by something that may never happen and life is really great again but I'm thinking I maybe in lala land thinking Herceptin means no more BC worries in my life - I'm 39!
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 12:49AM LouLou40 wrote: I was dx at 40 after finding a lump myself 2.1cm then another lump 1.5 cm showed up on mammagram that nobody could feel. Path showed triple positive and 2 nodes positive. I've finished Chemo and Rads now, just doing Herceptin 3 weekly and taking Arimidex as long as I stay post menopausal from Chemo otherwise will have an Ooph. Do have Ostopenia from Menopuase being small framed and below average weight most of my life, score just above the dx of osteoporosis so now taking Vit D and calcium as well as being monitored every 6 months. Chemo is just a distant memory now and life it pretty much back to normal now, very busy with 3 little ones and working full time.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 02:35AM LouLou40 wrote: Thanks Happy Trishia, you path is very similar to mine (multifocal, triple pos, 2 nodes pos) and like warrior said it's always great to hear from somebody dowing do well nearly 5 years down the track. I'm just coming up to my 1st year since diagnosis, feel great, chemo a distant memory and looking forward to 2010. Noticed some of you have been asking about SE's from Arimidex, well I've been on it for 3 months and haven't noticed any side effects, only mild hot flushes which I've had since Chemo sent me into Menopause in May. I have no bone or joint pain and go to the gym most days. I'm  busy with little kids and work full time, so thankfully the Arimidex dosen't slow me down at all.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 05:15PM LouLou40 wrote: Perhaps I'm deluded as well but I have never been worried about my diagnosis. Yes I was shocked at my diagnosis in Feb as I had no risk factors, a health freak and only 40, but not once have I thought I won't be cured after all the aggressive treatment I've had. I'm a very positive person by nature and was focused on getting through treatment and staying healthy which I done, I breezed through treatment with minimal side effects. Fortunately I'm surrounded by positive people as well, including my medical team. Only yesterday my Onc told me to eat well for my bones as I'll need good bone health for the next 50 years - bless him! I've finished my 6 months of Chemo in Aug, 6 weeks of Rads in Oct and now just continuing on Herceptin and Arimidex, BC it still feels like a bad dream, very surreal, but no, I'm at all worried about my future, I have little kids and they need their Mom. LL

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2010 04:24AM LouLou40 wrote: I didn't have any Dexamethosone during Taxol as I didn't like the SE's from it, I had it with my first AC and had blurred vision for 5 days post infusion, so decided I wouldn't take it again. I actually found the SE's from AC better without being on it. My Onc was OK with that. I  had no problems tolerating Taxol and no swelling anywhwere.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 10:57PM LouLou40 wrote: I'm coming up to 2 yrs post surgery and my nipple points left and I have a big chunk of tissue missing. My scar is faded to a white line and my boob is soft again, it was quite hard after Rads and I found massaging the scar with cream or oil helps with the lumpiness I did think a lot about having recon on my boob initially as I'm much smaller on my left , but now I'm used to the way it looks and so happy to have finished treatment and to be getting on with life and still have a boob even it it's not perfect.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy - breast still lookes weird InTwoPlaces lassman

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2011 02:22AM LouLou40 wrote: I just assumed I was stage 2 based on the size of my largest tumor 2.1cm and 2 positive nodes, have never discussed stage with my medical team, but I did have 3cm of subutaneous margin invovement, BS told me he removed all visible cancer and involved skin, my tumor was just below the surface of my skin and I did have puckering - Also had a 1.5cm deeper one. What I've read is that skin involvement that's not inflammatory dosen't increase recurrence risk and is possibly over staged at stage 3, my treatment was the same regardless, so not hung up on the staging
Posts.Title: anybody else stage 111 because of skin penetration? ctm1 mammalou

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 06:03AM LouLou40 wrote: My hair grew back during weekly Taxol, I did 4 AC first and lost most, but not all of my hair. After the 1st Taxol I lost all the remaining hair then by about week 3-4 of Taxol it started growing. I had a 3 week break after the 12 weeks of Taxol before I started Rads and by week 3 of Rads my hair was long enough to stop covering it. I had enough hair to color it before I went back to work the week after I finished Rads, so 9 weeks post Taxol, it was at least an inch long. Nothing bad happened it when I colored it, I chose a plant based brown color the first time, but have gone back to being a blonde as I was pre chemo. Sorry to say but all my eyebrows and lashes fell out during Taxol, they started growing back during Rads. I'm now a year post Chemo and my hair is just below collar, its now curly where it used to be straight, nut hey it's hair!
Posts.Title: Hair regrowth on Taxol Zachsmom LouLou40

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 04:01PM LouLou40 wrote: Another nurse here, graduated in 1991. I currently work for a global medical company as a clinical consultant in vascular access. My company has looked after me very well through my treatment, I was able to work form home during Chemo and they employed someone part-time to do my hospital workshops and customer visits. As soon as Chemo was over I went back full time to my usual position. It's nearly a year since I finished Chemo, only 6 weeks since I finished Herceptin and I'm now considering taking on some casual work in the acute care setting to keep my clinical skills up-to-date, just one shift a fortnight.  LL
